When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

The government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work

You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

The government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the results were finally made public

 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a seThe government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.

You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, eve

 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't man

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation,

 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages o

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. WHIch meant that af

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. WHIch meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenages

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Wch meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopele

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless.

 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do reas

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless.

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had neve

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experi

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunte

You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 A

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your b

But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compa

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.

 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the r

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that h

 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed.

You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using dif

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable.

 You volunteered immediately.

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, et.c

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from t

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for lat

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. WHat counted no

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.

 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.
 It had taken a year,

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.
 It had taken a year, and taken a toll on y

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.
 It had taken a year, and taken a toll on your body, but it wa

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.
 It had taken a year, and taken a toll on your body, but it was a price you were h

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.
 It had taken a year, and taken a toll on your body, but it was a price you were happy to pay. FOr th

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.
 It had taken a year, and taken a toll on your body, but it was a price you were happy to pay. FOr t

And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.

Until the announcement. 
The announcement that the drug had been discovered to have side effects.
 Fatal ones. And they were very unpleasant. 

While keeping them a secret, the government had been working on a cure for the side effects, but it was too late. Nothing seemed to work, and the research results were finally made public; everyone who had taken the drug could expect to die, painfully within the next 2-3 years. 
You were devastated.
 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless.

 Your children, grandchildren, everyone. There weren't many left in your generation, and most people had taken the drug between the ages of 18 and 21. Which meant that after all the deaths, the it would be left to teenagers to keep the world going. Everything seemed hopeless. 

But then, a new hope. One scientist suggested that they also do research involving those who had never taken the drug. But experimenting on children? Unacceptable. 
But then, a second scientist suggested that they could use the "Lost Generations" as test subjects.
 You volunteered immediately. 
And so, you were injected with a serum that was supposed to cure the side effects.
 And they recorded your body's reaction compared to the the reaction in those that had taken the drug. And then they tried again, and again, using different serums, in different doses, etc. 
And then, one day, they found a serum that worked.
 And it worked for everyone. People still worried about side effects from this new serum, but it was a matter for later. 
And so, the world was saved.
 It had taken a year, and taken a toll on your body, but it was a price you were happy to pay. For the first time in you lif

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

All things considered, you were pretty lucky to have lived to be 85 without being allowed to take the drug. Plenty of others in the "Lost Generations" had already passed. 
You were a bit of a rebel in your youth, but you had grown up to be a very responsible adult.
 And while your life may be nearing its end, you children, grandchildren, and other young relatives and friends were all lucky enough to be able to take the immortality/eternal youth drug. So you would say you had a good life.
